title: Chapter 2: NAS System Initialization and Development Environment Configuration
intro: After completing router configuration, we need to perform system-level configuration on the NAS device. This chapter will guide you through the necessary system settings to prepare for subsequent NFX service deployment.

webCenter.title: Disable Web Center Service
webCenter.important: **Important: Please ensure the Web Center service is disabled.**

why.title: Why Disable Web Center?
why.description: Asustor NAS's Web Center service defaults to using the following ports:
why.conflict: These ports completely conflict with the ports required by our NebulaForgeX Community services (particularly the [NFX-Edge](https://github.com/NebulaForgeX/NFX-Edge) reverse proxy service). If the Web Center service is running, reverse proxy services such as Traefik will be unable to start normally, causing the entire service stack deployment to fail.

steps.title: Steps
items: Log in to Asustor NAS's ADM (Asustor Data Master) management interface
Navigate to the "Services" menu
Find the "Web Center" service
Ensure the service is in "Stopped" or "Disabled" state
If the service is running, stop it immediately and disable auto-start

ssh.title: Enable SSH Service
ssh.description: SSH (Secure Shell) is a necessary tool for remote NAS management and command-line operations. After enabling the SSH service, you can connect to the NAS through command-line tools to perform subsequent configuration and deployment operations.

steps.title: Steps to Enable
items: In the ADM management interface, navigate to the "Services" menu
Find "SSH Service"
Enable the SSH service
Recommended security configuration options:
Change the default port (optional but recommended, avoid using port 22)
Disable root user direct login (recommended)
Enable key authentication (recommended)
Configure access whitelist (optional but recommended)

security.title: Security Recommendations
items: Use strong passwords or SSH key authentication
Consider using non-standard ports to reduce automated attacks
Regularly update the NAS system to get security patches
Only expose SSH service to the public network when necessary (recommended to use only on internal network)

applications.title: Install Required Applications
applications.description: Install the following required applications through Asustor's App Center. These applications are the fundamental components for running the NFX service stack.

docker.name: Docker Engine
docker.description: The NFX service stack runs entirely on Docker containers, and Docker Engine is the core dependency
docker.version: Recommended to use the latest stable version

git.name: Git
git.description: Used to clone NFX project repositories and manage configuration file versions

entware.name: Entware
entware.description: Provides additional Linux tools and software packages for NAS, especially solving the problem of incomplete NAS systems
entware.importance: Entware is crucial for subsequent Bash environment configuration

order.title: Recommended Installation Order
items: First install **Entware** (preparation for subsequent steps)
Then install **Git** (for project code management)
Finally install **Docker Engine** (core runtime environment)

problem.title: Problem Background
problem.description: Most commercial NAS systems (including Asustor) are built on streamlined Linux systems. To reduce system size and improve performance, they typically remove some "non-essential" standard Linux tools. Among them, `/bin/bash` is a common missing item.
problem.nasShell: NAS systems usually only provide `/bin/sh` (usually dash or busybox sh). Although functionally basic, for:
needs: Modern SSH clients (such as Cursor, certain VS Code extensions)
problem.conclusion: a complete Bash environment is essential.

solution.title: Solution: Install Bash Using Entware
solution.description: Since we have already installed the Entware package manager, we can use it to install a complete Bash shell.

step1.description: Choose the appropriate terminal tool based on your operating system:

cursor.title: Using Cursor IDE
cursor.description: Cursor is an AI-assisted code editor based on VS Code. If you plan to use Cursor to connect to the NAS via SSH for development:
reqItems: Must complete the above Bash installation and symbolic link creation steps
Cursor requires the system to provide the `/bin/bash` path to function properly

vscode.title: Using Visual Studio Code
vscode.description: If you use the standard Visual Studio Code:
reqItems: VS Code's Remote-SSH extension is less strict about `/bin/bash` requirements
VS Code can usually connect normally even without complete Bash
noteItems: VS Code is more flexible and can use the system's default shell
However, installing Bash is still recommended to ensure scripts and tools run properly

others.title: Using Other SSH Clients
others.description: If you use other SSH clients (such as PuTTY, Termius, SecureCRT, etc.), they are usually not affected by Bash installation, but installing Bash is still recommended because:
items: Many automation scripts require a Bash environment
Some development tools and scripts assume Bash is available
Better script compatibility and feature support

checklist.title: Configuration Completion Checklist
checklist.description: Before proceeding to the next chapter, please confirm that you have completed all of the following configurations:
items: ✅ Web Center service is disabled
✅ SSH service is enabled and can connect normally
✅ Docker Engine is installed and running properly
✅ Git is installed
✅ Entware is installed
✅ Bash is installed and symbolic link created
✅ Can connect to NAS via SSH normally
checklist.conclusion: **After completing all the above configurations, your NAS development environment is ready, and you can start deploying the NFX service stack!**
